hey, welcome to 12tone! repetition does weird
things to the human brain.

like, right now, I'm just talking, and it

to transform.

ok, that's enough of that, but quick question:
did it kinda sound like I was singing just
then? did you at least hear a melody?

I mean, check this out: (bang) to my ears,
at least, that's definitely what I was singing,

like most perception tricks, this won't work
for everyone, so don't worry if you just heard

somewhere in those repeating phrases, something
changed.
so… why?
(tick, tick, tick, tick, tock)

this is called the speech to song illusion,
and it was first discovered by accident by
UCSD psychology professor Dianna Deutsch.

Deutsch is an expert on auditory illusions,
and in 1995 she was putting the finishing

touches on an instructional CD called Musical
Illusions and Paradoxes.

she was dialing in the final mix, and in order
to do that she'd grabbed a random phrase and
set it on loop while she played with settings.

pretty quickly, though, she noticed that the
definitely-spoken phrase she'd picked was

starting to sound a lot like singing which,
as you might imagine, was pretty interesting
to an expert on auditory illusions.

she featured the phenomenon on her next CD,
Phantom Words and Other Curiosities, in 2003,

and in 2011, along with Trevor Henthorn and
Rachel Lapidis, she published a full paper
on it, with experiments and everything.

the first test was pretty straightforward:
they brought a group of people in and played

them the phrase over and over, asking them
to rate it on a scale from 1 to 5, where 1

was exactly like speech and 5 was exactly
like singing, and given that I'm bothering

to make a video about this, you can probably
guess the results here: after one iteration,

the average score was pretty close to 1, meaning
everyone heard it as speech.

however, after ten repetitions, that average
score shot up to almost 4, which means a lot
of people were hearing it as sung.
so, sure, the phenomenon exists.
that's the easy part.

the hard part is figuring out how and why,
and to help with that, Deutsch also played
with a couple other variables.

specifically, she had three test groups: in
the first, she just played the sample unmodified.
that's the one whose numbers I gave you before.

in the second group, she changed the pitch
of each statement, so the first one was normal,

the second one a little high, the third one
pretty low, and so on.

in the third group, she kept the pitch the
same, but jumbled the order of syllables in

each statement, so you were hearing the same
words spoken the same way, but not in a consistent
pattern.

and what did she find from this? well, again,
you can probably guess: in both cases, the
spoken words continued to sound like speech.
there was no transformation, no illusory singing.

after 10 repetitions, people in the transposing
experiment rated it a 2 out of 5, and in the

jumbled one it was even lower, implying that
the repetition needs to be pretty exact in
order for this to actually work.

but Deutsch's second experiment is a lot more
interesting to me: in this one, instead of

just having people listen, she brought in
a bunch of choir singers and asked them to
reproduce what they heard.

these were broken up into two groups: the
first group heard the phrase once, while the
second heard it ten times.

all the recordings of their reproductions
were then played for a third group, who rated
each one as either speech or song.

and the results were striking: over 97% of
the time, listeners identified the version

from the repeat group as sung and the non-repeat
group as spoken, which implies that the listeners

were experiencing not just a change in categorization
but a genuine shift in perception.

that is, not only were they describing the
sound as singing, they were actually hearing
it in a way that sounds like singing.

that may seem obvious, but let's compare it
to another repetition-based illusion: semantic
satiation.

this is where, if you hear the same word enough
times, it stops sounding like a real word.

so, like, if I made you listen to me saying
"music" a hundred times, you might lose track

of its meaning, but if I asked you to tell
me what you heard, the thing you said would
still probably sound like a word to me.
but this is just the tip of the iceberg.

we've got recordings now, which means we can
compare the actual sounds.

specifically, we can look at the pitch of
each reproduction.

English isn't a particularly tonal language,
so specific frequencies don't carry much semantic
meaning.

as such, if I say a sentence and ask you to
repeat it back, you're not likely to do it
with the exact same notes I did.

instead, you'll adjust it to your comfortable
speaking range, because that's just how you

talk. and the specific intervals are also
unlikely to be preserved: you'll probably

have the same basic contour, but you're not
gonna worry about the exact amount my voice
rose or fell on any given syllable.
that's just not how it works.

and when we look at the reproductions in Deutsch's
experiment, that's what we see.

I mean, there's some range similarities, because
the test subjects were all choir singers with

relatively high voices, in order to match
the recording, but when they only had one
listen, the end results still varied wildly.

however, when they had ten listens, all the
singers converged on a single melody. in fact,

on her website, Deutsch has a clip of all
the recordings played simultaneously, and
it straight-up sounds like a chorus.

but, and this is my favorite part of the result,
the melody they converged on wasn't the original
melody. at least, not quite.

the researchers compared the notes the singers
sang to the pitches from the original spoken

phrase, and it was close, but they also compared
it to a hypothetical melody they'd written

based on it in the key of B major, and it
was significantly closer.

the singers had heard an arbitrarily moving
human voice but had produced not the movement

of that voice but a strongly tonal melody
inspired by it.

effectively, not only were they hearing the
line as a melody, but they were mentally adjusting

it into a better one, or at least one that
would be more familiar to their Western-trained
ears.
that's amazing.

of course, as a singer myself, I do have to
add a quick caveat to that: singers spend

a lot of time building muscle memory for specific
notes and intervals, so it's possible that

the transformation to a strong tonal melody
took place not at the perception stage, but
at the reproduction.

that is, they may have heard it as the notes
it was but then, when they went to sing it,

it came out as the notes they were most familiar
with.

I doubt that's the whole story, but it's probably
part of it.

anyway, after Deutsch and her collaborators
published, a lot of other psychologists started
looking into the effect.

I don't have time to cover all of them, but
there is one more that I want to highlight.

in 2014, Falk, Rathcke, and Dalla Bella published
a paper where they tried to identify the specific

characteristics of speech that made the illusion
possible.

that is, did it always happen, or did it depend
on the structure of the phrase or of the sound

of the speaker's voice? they tried two pitch-based
and two rhythmic variations, and found that,

while the rhythmic variations had no significant
impact on whether or not the transformation

occurred, the pitch-based ones definitely
did.

the strongest impact was tonal stability:
effectively, if every syllable is sliding

around in pitch, it's harder to hear a real
melody.

they also found a marginal difference when
they added in some perfect fifths, to prompt

the listener to hear things tonally. on the
surface, this is, again, obvious: if you make

something sound more melodic, you're more
likely to hear it as a melody.

I mean, duh. but playing around with these
sorts of variables helps us better understand
what sounding more melodic actually means.

this study also had another interesting twist:
in Deutsch's version, they only compared the

results after one and ten listens, but here
the authors looked at participants's ratings

after every repeat, so they could measure
not just whether or not the transformation

took place, but also when, and they found
that Deutsch's initial estimate of 10 was

really conservative: if the transformation
was going to occur, it usually happened around

the 3rd to 5th time through, which means our
brains are abandoning the speech interpretation
really quickly.

they also found some other cool results here:
for starters, while the rhythmic changes they

made had no significant impact on whether
the illusion worked, they did have an effect
on how long it took.

but the best part is that these results directly
address a concern I had with Deutsch's test.

you see, in both of Deutsch's experiments,
she'd used only participants with a minimum

5 years of musical experience, a group that,
as you might imagine, is unusually good at
recognizing melodies.

this was fine for an initial study, but it
does mean that it's hard to generalize her
results.

on the other hand, this new study included
both musicians and non-musicians, and found

that there was, in fact, a negative correlation:
people with more musical training took longer
to experience the illusion.

the authors don't go into why, but my guess
is that we're just more familiar with what
music is "supposed" to sound like.

which brings me to the final experiment I
wanna talk about, from a 2015 paper by Margulis,

Simchy-Gross, and Black, which looked exclusively
at non-musicians.

the authors here were interested in seeing
how language affects the illusion, so they

gathered a bunch of native English speakers
and played them repeated phrases in 7 different

languages: English, Catalan, Portuguese, French,
Croatian, Hindi, and Irish.

the theory was that some of these languages,
like Portuguese, would be easier for native

English speakers to pronounce, whereas others,
like Hindi, would be more difficult, and they
wanted to see if that had an impact.
and… it did.
quite a lot, in fact.

the harder the language was for the listeners
to pronounce, the stronger the illusion was.

the difference in ratings on the hard languages
was more than double the difference on the

easy ones, which implies that the less familiar
we are with certain vocalizations, the more
easily we accept them as music.

and, to be clear, they also double-checked
their assumptions about which languages were

hard by asking the participants to rate them,
so we can be fairly certain that the categories
are accurate.

so what's the point of all this? well, we've
known for a long time that speech and singing

are different, but what we've struggled to
nail down is what exactly that difference
is.

for the most part, it's been assumed that
the answer lies in their acoustic properties:

singing contains longer, more stable pitches
that tend to move in clear, predictable patterns,

while speech involves sudden, unstructured
frequency slides, and more pronounced changes

in harmonics caused by strongly enunciated
consonants.

but the speech to song illusion challenges
that interpretation.

again, at the beginning, the repeated phrases
were acoustically identical, and yet over

time spoken words became sung. if the difference
between speech and singing is all down to
acoustic properties, that shouldn't be possible.

maybe this all comes down to our old friend
semantic satiation.

if I say a word over and over, the part of
your brain responsible for interpreting its
meaning just gets bored and shuts down.

it's possible the same thing is happening
here: if the phrase repeats enough times,

the parts of your brain that process speech
recognize that it's clearly not trying to

convey speech-based information anymore, so
they step aside and let someone else have
a go at making sense of it.
or maybe not.
maybe it's something else entirely.

the human brain is weird and difficult to
understand.

there's lots factors at work here, and the
first papers on this phenomenon are less than
a decade old.

this is spicy new science, hot off the presses,
and there's a lot more work to be done before
we can fully explain what's going on.

but in the meantime, it's a good reminder
that any attempt to rigidly define what is

and isn't music is probably going to fail
in the face of human perception, because human
perception is really, really complicated.
